close_symbols: struct MHD_Connection (definition and field names: next, prev, daemon, ...)
struct MHD_Daemon (definition and fields: new_connections_head, new_connections_tail, have_new, new_connections_mutex, ...)
NULL, false, bool (type/definitions used in the function)
explanation:
To decide whether this function violates the MISRA rule about well-formed for-loops we must inspect any code that can affect loop control variables or that is executed as part of a loop body. The items above are required for that inspection:

- DLL_remove: Called inside the loop and likely a macro. It may modify the local loop-control variables (local_head/local_tail) by name or contain internal loops/side-effects. Its definition is essential to know whether the loop-control object is modified in the loop body or whether it expands to a for-statement that must be checked for MISRA compliance.

- new_connection_process_: Called from the loop body; the behaviour of any for-loop must consider called functions as part of the loop body. We need the function body to determine whether it modifies any loop counter or contains ill-formed for-loops affecting the outer analysis.

- MHD_DLOG: Called in the loop body (conditionally). As a macro/function it could have side-effects or contain loops; inspect its definition to ensure it does not affect loop counters or contain non-compliant for-loops.

- struct MHD_Connection (definition and fields): The code accesses c->daemon and DLL_remove operates on connection nodes; the struct field names (next/prev/daemon) determine how DLL_remove or other macros access/modify connection pointers which may be used as loop control objects.

- struct MHD_Daemon (definition and fields): The function reads/writes new_connections_head/tail and have_new. Knowing their exact types and whether any of their accessors/macros expand to loops or side-effects is necessary to determine if a loop counter/object is modified outside the loop header.

- MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ / MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_: These are macros/wrappers used in this function. Their expansions could (rarely) include loops or side-effects; include them to be certain they don't interact with loop control variables.

- MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_: Macro used in an assertion. Its expansion could contain expressions that affect analysis (e.g. side-effects) — include to be safe.

- mhd_assert: Assertion macro — its expansion may call functions or builtins (e.g. __builtin_unreachable) that could contain loops or side-effects; include to ensure no hidden loop constructs or modifications of loop counters.

- NULL, false, bool: Definitions/types used for loop control (the loop uses NULL checks and boolean flags). Confirm their standard definitions to ensure no macros hide unexpected behaviour.

Collecting these symbols lets the next analyst (a) determine whether any for-loops exist or are introduced by macros within the body of this function, (b) verify whether any called function or macro invoked from the loop body modifies objects that would serve as a loop counter, and (c) inspect any for-statements in called code for the three MISRA clauses (initialization, condition side-effects, and increment-only modifications).
